title: Champion of Human Rights and Former UNFPA Executive Director, Dr. Nafis Sadik, passes away at 92 - USA for UNFPA

quotes: Dr. Nafis Sadik, former Executive Director of UNFPA, passed away on August 14 of natural causes at age 92.
Prior to her work with the United Nations, Sadik worked as a civilian medical officer in Pakistani armed forces hospitals from 1954 to 1963.
In 1966, she began serving on the Pakistan Central Family Planning Council.
Sadik joined UNFPA in 1971 and became Assistant Executive Director in 1977.
Sadik joined UNFPA in 1971 and became Assistant Executive Director in 1977.
She was Executive Director of UNFPA from 1978 to 2000 and was the first woman to lead the agency.
In 1990, Sadik became Secretary-General of the 1994 International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD) in Cairo, Egypt.
In 1990, Sadik became Secretary-General of the 1994 International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD) in Cairo, Egypt.

Since 1994, UNFPA and other international bodies have worked toward providing women with greater access to secondary and higher education, decreasing infant and child death, and increasing access to sexual and reproductive health services, including family planning.

organizations.name: UNFPA
quotes: Champion of Human Rights and Former UNFPA Executive Director, Dr. Nafis Sadik, passes away at 92
Sadik joined UNFPA in 1971 and became Assistant Executive Director in 1977.
She was Executive Director of UNFPA from 1978 to 2000 and was the first woman to lead the agency.

In a statement regarding her passing, Dr. Natalia Kanem, UNFPA’s current Executive Director, said Sadik was “a trailblazer who made indelible contributions to advancing sexual and reproductive health and rights, women’s leadership, and global development.”

organizations.name: Dow Medical College
quotes: Born in British-ruled India, Sadik received her medical degree from Dow Medical College in Karachi, Pakistan.

organizations.name: Pakistan Central Family Planning Council

The ICPD encouraged world leaders to invest in the well-being of women and girls for the betterment of all people.
